abstract.text: Explore the various Wi-Fi APIs available on iOS and their expected use cases.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: iOS does not have a general-purpose API for Wi-Fi scanning and configuration.  However, it does support a wide range of special-purpose Wi-Fi APIs.  This technote lists some use cases supported by those special-purpose APIs.
If your app helps the user navigate an internet hotspot — a Wi-Fi network where the user must interact with the network to gain access to the wider internet — adopt the
API.
To use
you must first be granted a special entitlement (
) by Apple.  For information on how to apply for this, see
is
only
useful for hotspot integration. There are both technical and business restrictions that prevent it from being used for other tasks, such as accessory integration or Wi-Fi based location.

content.text: Add an accessory to the user’s network

inlineContent.text: If you’re creating a hardware accessory and you want to make it easy for the user to add it to their local network, your best option is to build your accessory with that in mind.  Use one of these approaches:
Wireless Accessory Configuration (WAC) — The user can configure a WAC-capable accessory directly in Settings.  Optionally, use
to integrate accessory configuration directly in your app.
HomeKit — Call
APIs like
to ask the system to scan for, pair, and configure any unpaired HomeKit accessories .
To add WAC or HomeKit support to your accessory, join the
If your accessory does not support WAC or HomeKit, you can build an accessory configuration experience on top of
, although this will not be as seamless as the WAC and HomeKit accessory experience.  For an example of how you might approach this, see
If your app needs to temporarily join a Wi-Fi network — for example, you want to interact with a Wi-Fi enabled accessory with its own independent network — use
and set
to true.  For more details, see
If you’re working with a Wi-Fi accessory, use
to simplify discovery and configuration of your accessory.

Some apps need to configure the iOS device to permanently join a Wi-Fi network, as if the user had selected the network in Settings > Wi-Fi.  For example, an app from an ISP might do this to get the user’s iOS device on to the Wi-Fi network published by a new DSL gateway that they’ve just installed.  If your app needs to do this, use
and set
to false.  For more details, see
If your goal is to communicate with other nearby devices, look at:
framework
framework
Both of these support networking over peer-to-peer Wi-Fi.  In Network framework you must opt in to this via the
property.  For more information about peer-to-peer networking, see
The on-the-wire protocol used by these peer-to-peer networking APIs is not documented for third-party use, so this technique only works between Apple devices.
If you’d like to use Wi-Fi data to determine the device’s location, use Core Location.  This locates the device using a wide variety of techniques, including Wi-Fi.  For more information, see
If you need to know the name of the device’s current Wi-Fi network, call
.  That method requires iOS 14 or later.  On older systems, call

abstract.text: Enable privacy-preserving discovery and configuration of accessories.
An object you use to scan for wireless accessories and configure them for use with the user’s app.
Performs the process of setting up accessories with Apple Home.
Support peer-to-peer connectivity and the discovery of nearby devices.
Create network connections to send and receive data using transport and security protocols.
A Boolean that enables peer-to-peer link technologies for connections and listeners.
Restricts the lifetime of a configuration to the operating status of the app that created it.
Fetches information about the current Wi-Fi network.
Associate an iOS device with an accessory’s network to deliver network configuration information.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Configuring a Wi-Fi accessory to join a network
